Award.AwardTitle: The role of behavior in the establishment of novel traits
Award.AbstractNarration: The Pacific field cricket has been introduced to Hawaii, where it is subject to a parasitoid fly that finds its host by listening to the calling song of the male crickets and depositing larvae that burrow inside the cricket and eventually kill it. This puts the cricket in a dilemma, because calling is his means to attract a mate, but also places him in danger. In some Hawaiian populations, 50-90% of the male crickets now have a mutated wing that lacks the apparatus necessary for calling. They are thus unable to call, which protects them from the fly, but they then face challenges attracting a mate. This project examines the consequences of such extraordinarily rapid evolution (the change occurred over 16-20 generations) for the mating behavior of the crickets. The hypothesis for the ability of this novel mutation to become established is that pre-existing behavioral plasticity has enabled the silent crickets to achieve reproductive success. The mutation and its effects will be monitored in the field, and laboratory experiments will examine how early experience with the acoustic environment influences mating behavior. During presentations to university students and the public this research provides a compelling introduction to many topics in evolutionary biology and animal behavior because it features familiar animals ? crickets ? in an attractive place ? Hawaii ? evading an unpleasant ?Alien?-like parasite via natural selection, which then places the males in a dilemma with regard to reproduction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Pacific field cricket is native to subtropical Australia and islands in the Pacific such as Fiji, Tahiti, and Samoa. It has been introduced to Hawaii, where a parasitic fly uses the mate-attracting song of the male crickets to locate a host. Once a fly finds a cricket, she deposits larvae on and around him. The larvae then burrow into the male’s body, eating the tissues of the cricket while he is still alive. After about a week, the fly larvae emerge from the cricket, killing him in the process. This situation sets up an evolutionary dilemma for the male crickets: the more they call, the better off they are in attracting females, but the more likely they are to also attract a lethal parasite. The cricket and fly co-occur on three of the Hawaiian islands: Kauai, the Big Island of Hawaii, and Oahu.

Our research examines the outcome of such conflicting selection, and has been focused for this award on a recent development in the system, the rapid (fewer than 20 generations) establishment of a new mutant male type, called flatwing, that has modified wing structures and hence cannot call. Such individuals are protected from the fly, but have obvious difficulties in mate attraction. We suggested that the flatwings were able to become established despite their obvious disadvantage in mating because of pre-existing behavioral plasticity.  From the crickets’ perspective, the spread of the flatwings means that their world has become relatively silent.  But such silence could arise from other sources besides the appearance of a novel mutation, including low population density, a female-biased sex ratio, or poor local habitat quality.  Perhaps the crickets already possess flexible behavioral “rules of thumb”, such as “when few conspecifics are heard, move toward a caller”, that enable them to accommodate such environmental variation.  Such rules would have been available when the mutant wing morphology appeared, and hence enabled the flatwings to find mates.  In other words, the flatwings may be exposing heretofore under-appreciated plasticity in the behavior of the crickets, which like most insects have always been assumed to be automatons that cannot alter their behavior to suit the circumstances.

As part of this project, we developed mathematical models of the cricket’s behavior. We found that the optimal behavior switched abruptly from calling to not calling, depending on the sex ratio, population density, and other features of the environment. We suspect that even with many of the flies present, we would never see only the flatwing morph in the population.  

We also examined the response of females to the newly silent environment, discovering that exposure to song in the lab during their adult stage decreased response to calling song, while experience of calling songs during the juvenile stage had a much smaller effect. Mate choice behaviors of adult females are therefore more plastic than previously appreciated, and this plasticity may have important evolutionary implications.

Males from Kauai, where the new morph has been established the longest, move around more than males from other locations, including both another Hawaiian island (Oahu) as well as a Pacific site where the parasitoid flies have never occurred (the Cook Islands). Interestingly, the effect of acoustic environment seems to be more pronounced in the Kauai crickets than in those from Oahu, perhaps because selection has had longer to act there since the mutation appeared. These other behavioural changes might help the crickets accommodate to the spread of the mutants.
